item.title: What is QMSTR?
item.description: Quartermaster is an integrated free and open source software (FOSS) toolchain that implements industry best practises of license compliance management. It is FOSS because the QMSTR community believes that software that manages FOSS compliance becomes critical infrastructure to the wider open source community and should itself be FOSS. QMSTR is developed in collaboration with users, legal experts and other interested stakeholders. QMSTR: A command-line workflow toolchain for FOSS compliance QMSTR is implemented as a command line toolchain.

item.title: Why QMSTR?
item.description: A key impulse for the development of QMSTR was the realization that there is still no industry standard for FOSS compliance tooling, and the understanding that the management of software copyright and license compliance in FOSS needs to improve. While from a legal perspective, every obligation and liability technically boils down to managing the risk of running into trouble and the mitigation of possible damage, we believe that this is not the right mindset to approach FOSS license compliance.

item.title: How to participate
item.description: The QMSTR development process is open to everybody to participate and contribute. The QMSTR community aims at a maximum of openness, transparency and accountability, and at minimizing barriers for newcomers. There are three pillars to the work of the community: An open development process: Development is organized into quarterly milestones made up of bi-weekly sprints. Requirements are collaboratively developed. The QMSTR community offers mentoring opportunities for newcomer users and potential contributors.

item.title: Development environment
item.description: To create a local development environment for Quartermaster, follow these instructions. The master by default runs in a container. See below for more details. Prerequisites Quartermaster leverages Protobuf & GRPC for the master - client communication. The protoc Protobuf compiler needs to be installed together with the Go protobuf library and generator. The later will be installed via the Makefile. Host machine preparation Install the depencencies: If you are running an Ubuntu machine:

item.title: Node labels in Quartermaster
item.description: Node labels are used to flexibly add data to nodes based on key-value pairs. For example, if a build process consists of multiple stages, a label can be used to mark nodes with the stage during which they are created. Or a target program generated during the build could be marked with a release milestone name. The labelling functionality allows for user-defined concepts to be flexibly represented in the knowledge graph.

item.title: qmstr
item.description: qmstr qmstr performs Quartermaster client-side operations Synopsis qmstr performs Quartermaster operations that have only client-side effects. It does not require a QMSTR master to be available. Options -h, --help help for qmstr -v, --verbose enable diagnostics SEE ALSO qmstr dev-generate-reference - Generate command line reference in the specified path qmstr run - Run a shell command with QMSTR instrumentation qmstr validate - Validate a package against a manifest Auto generated by spf13/cobra on 6-Jul-2020

item.title: qmstr dev-generate-reference
item.description: qmstr dev-generate-reference Generate command line reference in the specified path Synopsis Generate the command line reference in Markdown format. The pages will contain metadata to integrate into a Hugo web site. qmstr dev-generate-reference [path] [flags] Options -b, --baseURL string The base URL used in the reference (optional) -h, --help help for dev-generate-reference Options inherited from parent commands -v, --verbose enable diagnostics SEE ALSO qmstr - qmstr performs Quartermaster client-side operations Auto generated by spf13/cobra on 6-Jul-2020

item.title: qmstr run
item.description: qmstr run Run a shell command with QMSTR instrumentation Synopsis run executes the argument after applying temporary QMSTR instrumentation. For example, “qmstr make” sets up a QMSTR instrumented environment, then executes “make”, and finally restores the environment and deletes all temporary files. The environment variable QMSTR_INSTRUMENTATION_HOME will be defined to point to the QMSTR instrumentation directory. qmstr run [flags] Options -h, --help help for run -i, --instdir string Create instrumentation in this directory (optional) -k, --keep Keep the created directories instead of cleaning up.

item.title: qmstr validate
item.description: qmstr validate Validate a package against a manifest Synopsis validate needs at least one argument, the package file. Depending on the package format the manifest can be internal and/or external. For example: qmstr validate curl-a.b.c.deb curl-a.b.c.deb.spdx qmstr validate [flags] Options -h, --help help for validate Options inherited from parent commands -v, --verbose enable diagnostics SEE ALSO qmstr - qmstr performs Quartermaster client-side operations Auto generated by spf13/cobra on 6-Jul-2020

item.title: qmstrctl
item.description: qmstrctl qmstrctl controls and manages the QMSTR master Synopsis qmstrctl controls and manages the QMSTR master process. It provides commands to run, quit and configure the master and to interact with the QMSTR knowledge base. qmstrctl [flags] Options --cserv string connect to control service -h, --help help for qmstrctl --verbose enable diagnostics SEE ALSO qmstrctl add-graph - Add partial graphs from a configuration file qmstrctl analyze - Start analysis on the QMSTR master qmstrctl clean - Remove stopped QMSTR containers qmstrctl connect - Connect nodes with specific edges qmstrctl copy - Copy results from the QMSTR master qmstrctl create - Create a new node qmstrctl delete - Delete node from the database qmstrctl describe - Print description of the node qmstrctl dev-generate-reference - Generate command line reference in the specified path qmstrctl disconnect - Disconnect nodes with specific edges qmstrctl logs - Print QMSTR master logs qmstrctl quit - Quit QMSTR master qmstrctl report - Start report on the QMSTR master qmstrctl snapshot - Take snapshot of the QMSTR master state qmstrctl spawn - Spawn a container adjacent to the master and execute a command qmstrctl start - Start the QMSTR master qmstrctl status - Print the QMSTR master status qmstrctl update - Update nodes qmstrctl version - Print the version of qmstrctl qmstrctl wait - Wait until the QMSTR master is ready Auto generated by spf13/cobra on 6-Jul-2020

item.title: qmstrctl add-graph
item.description: qmstrctl add-graph Add partial graphs from a configuration file Synopsis Add missing files nodes and the connection between them. Provide the extra information you want to include in the database, through a configuration yaml file. qmstrctl add-graph [config_file] [flags] Options -h, --help help for add-graph Options inherited from parent commands --cserv string connect to control service --verbose enable diagnostics SEE ALSO qmstrctl - qmstrctl controls and manages the QMSTR master Auto generated by spf13/cobra on 6-Jul-2020

item.title: qmstrctl connect
item.description: qmstrctl connect Connect nodes with specific edges Synopsis Usage: qmstrctl connect … Connect to Node Node(s) . item.title: qmstrctl start
item.description: qmstrctl start Start the QMSTR master Synopsis Start the QMSTR master at a random port in the range between 6787 and 7811. qmstrctl start [flags] Options -c, --config string Path to qmstr configuration file (default "qmstr.yaml") -h, --help help for start --image string provide a custom docker image to run QMSTR master --seed string Replay dgraph export on init -t, --timeout int timeout after the specified time (seconds).
